passages.name: Warn Richard
passages.text:
It takes me some time to craft my response.

//Lindy
I don’t know, Richard. I really don’t think it’s going to work out. With you being so much older, and with your track record I have a bad feeling about it.//

It takes him some time to reply back.

//Richard
I really want this to work. I really like Ari, okay?//

I bite my lip, looking up as the bell rings. There isn’t much I can say - either way, I better talk to Ari when I get back home.

[[I wonder if he feels the same|At Home]]

links.text: I wonder if he feels the same

passages.name: Text Ari
passages.text:
Maybe he’s actually in a good mood today. I snort at my wishful thinking as my thumbs punch the screen. Still, I should go about this carefully.

//Lindy
Ari, I read that you’re dating Richard now - I would say congratulations, if it weren’t for the fact that he’s TOO OLD FOR YOU.//

Hm. Maybe that was a bit too direct. 

As expected, Ari’s reaction is swift.

//Ari
fuck off//

//Lindy
Should I give you a list of reasons why a high school freshman shouldn’t be dating a senior?//

//Ari
omg lindy why//

//Lindy
1: power dynamics//

//Ari
STOP//

//Lindy
Seriously, when did you two even meet?!//

//Ari
If u MUST know, it wa after ur game that yall dragged me to//

//Ari
why’d i have to come, anyway?i hate football//

//Lindy
Of course you had to come, you’d be in bed all day otherwise - AND ARI THE GAME WAS THREE DAYS AGO//

//Ari
So?//

//Lindy
ARI//

//Ari
Wut//

//Lindy
YOU CAN’T JUST JUMP INTO A RELATIONSHIP LIKE THAT//

//Ari
y not

Ari
besides he asked me//

//Lindy
What

Ari
he was like wanna go out and i was like sure whatever

Lindy
I 

Ari
he’s smart at least

Ari
u ok

Ari
i can hear ur brain breaking from over here

Lindy
That’s… just… not how it WORKS

Ari
so wut r u like the dating police or something

Ari
there some dating handbook im not aware of

Ari
look

Ari
richard? he actually makes me feel something other than doom and gloom. its nice not feeling sad or angry or dead all the time for once

Lindy
I…//

<<choice "Warn Ari">>
<<choice "Wish Ari Good Luck">>

passages.name: I need to help him
passages.text:
The door’s locked. 

I knock, carefully, gently. “Ari? Are you okay?”

“Go away!”

I could hear him trying to play off the thickness in his throat as anger.

“Please, let me in, what’s wrong?”

“Go away.”

I press my hand against the wood. “Ari.”

I hear something, like someone sinking to the ground with their back against the door. 

“Please go away." I can barely hear him.

[[The door’s still locked.|go to the group meeting]]

passages.name: Richard
passages.text:
“I don’t want to talk about him,” Ari snaps almost immediately.

[[His eyes are filled with hurt.|Talk about something else]]

links.text: His eyes are filled with hurt.

passages.name: He's not the boss of you.
passages.text:
Once upon a time, such a statement would snap Ari awake, eyes narrowed and lips twisted in a scowl. Of course, I’m the only boss of me, he would snap and immediately goes and does his own thing. 

But now, Ari only sighs heavily. “Whatever, I’m tired. I got to go, Lindy.” He hangs up, and I start to get the feeling that something is very, very wrong. 

[[something is wrong]]

passages.name: our room
passages.text:
I stare after him, a sinking feeling in my stomach. Great, what do I do now?

<<choice "Rush after him">>
<<choice "Give him space">>
<<choice "Go to him after he has time to cool down">>

passages.name: Talk about something else
passages.text:
About what?

<<choice "Talk About Mycle">>
<<choice "The broken robot">>
<<choice "Richard">>
<<choice "Anything">>
[[Nothing]]

passages.name: He'll just yell at me
passages.text:
I pace. I worry. 

Ari doesn’t come out for dinner. 

[[But I know he won’t talk to me.|go to the group meeting]]

links.text: But I know he won’t talk to me.

passages.name: Talk about the bruise
passages.text:
He immediately stiffens, looking everywhere except me. His walls of defense fly up.

My heart sinks. 

“It’s nothing,” he says, the lie betrayed by the sound squeezing through the tightening of his throat. 

[[But he won’t say anything else.|go to the group meeting]]

links.text: But he won’t say anything else.

passages.name: Richard Norbrook
passages.text:
[img[Richard's Pic]]

Age: 17 (Senior)
Gender: Male
Football pro and science geek 
Values: popularity and intellect
He always gets what he wants

[[Go Back|Begin]]

passages.name: We pick up the pieces, and we carry them to wherever our paths take us.
passages.text:
If You're There
Written by Serene, coded by Emil

Images drawn by Serene

Made in Twine

~ Thank you so much for playing! It was really a joy to write these characters of mine. I truly aimed to tackle these issues in a sensitive and thoughtful manner, and I hope it came together that way. Thank you again!

passages.name: Start
passages.text:
Hi.

[img[Lindy's Pic]]

My name's Lindy.

I'm just sitting here with my friends eating lunch when I see it.

[[Begin]]

Note: includes non-graphic mentions of abuse and strong language

passages.name: Finally
passages.text:
Ari gives me an exasperated look. I quickly cursed myself for my loose tongue, wondering just how long and how hard Ari’s struggle with the decision had been. “Will you help me or not?” 

<<choice "Of course">>
<<choice "You should do this yourself">>

passages.name: Ari Bhardwaj
passages.text:
[img[Ari's Pic]]

Age: 14 (Freshman)
Gender: Male (trans)
Dead inside
Values: intelligence, interesting stuff, kindness
Has no more fucks to give.

[[Go Back|Begin]]

passages.name: I've got your back
passages.text:
Relief. “Thanks,” he says.

<<choice "showdown">>

passages.name: the place
passages.text:
I pull into a parking space, my heart pounding, my stomach a squirming pile of nerves. God, why do I feel so nervous?

I duck out of the car and slam the door shut, looking across the street to the movie theater. I move, one foot in front of the other, until I’m running. I pull the door open and enter, warmth smelling like popcorn spilling across my face. 

Ari’s standing under a movie poster, staring up at it as if it held all the answers. 

“Ari!” I call, panting.

He turns. I reach his side, gasping for breath. “Are you okay?”

His eyes dig into mine. “I want to go home,” he says quietly. 

“We’re going, we’re going,” I promise. Ari tugs his coat tighter around him. I look around. “Where’s Richard?”

“Still in the theater,” Ari says. “I told him I needed to go to the bathroom.” He shrugs. “It was technically true. I did need to go.”

I smile a little. “Do you think he’ll be angry?”

“Just a little. That’s why I’m sending him a text later,” Ari says. 

“Alright,” I say, walking towards the doors.

"Lindy," Ari says from behind me.

I turn. "Yeah?"

He observes the floor. "Thanks," he mutters.

[[...No problem. Let's go.|the break up]]

passages.name: Give him space
passages.text:
I hear him screaming in frustration and something crash in his room, which only fueled my determination to give him the space he needs. 

I don’t see Ari come out out for the rest of the night. When I open the door, the lights are out. His snores are the only sound.

[[It’s quiet…|go to the group meeting]]

passages.name: aftermath
passages.text:
Ari breaks up with Richard in the middle of the crowded cafeteria. 

Cleverly cautious, yet clumsily fumbling with Richard’s emotions.

The two of them make a scene, loud and angry. Somehow, I think, they both desperately wanted to both hurt the other and keep the other from hurt. But they are both clumsy with their words, imprecise, and it hurts even more.

Despite Richard’s desperation to keep his cool and his reputation, his temper is such a hard thing to keep. At one point he tries to drag Ari off to talk in private, and Ari fights back, snapping what’s left of Richard’s temper.

By the time a teacher pulls Richard off of him Ari is badly shaken, as bruised as one would get in a school fight, his heart another story. 

Richard gets suspended. Kicked off the team. Mycle’s guardian is a lawyer. She helps out.

And Ari…

Ari survives.

I can’t stop kicking myself for not being there. Was that not the most important thing I was supposed to learn in this whole mess? To be there?

But time marches on. Ari forgets to take his medicine sometimes and I remind him. Mycle reaches out to greet Ari with a hug every time he sees him. When I look over Ari’s shoulder I see him looking up stuff about testosterone and binders. Mycle comes over more often. Ari hesitantly begins to make more friends. Time is moving forward, and we’re not being left behind.

[[We pick up the pieces, and we carry them to wherever our paths take us.]]

links.text: We pick up the pieces, and we carry them to wherever our paths take us.

destination.name: We pick up the pieces, and we carry them to wherever our paths take us.

passages.name: What do you need me for?
passages.text:
I almost expect Ari’s eyes to dart away, but they held my gaze as he scowled. “While I’m not scared,” he says, crossing his arms, “it would be nice if you had my back. I don’t think texting’s going to cut it.”

<<choice "I've got your back">>
<<choice "You should face him on your own">>

passages.name: Ask him if he's okay
passages.text:
There is a long, contemplative silence. Concern begins to spiral up in me, and I step forward, opening my mouth only for something to smack me in the face.

I sputter as the pillow flopped to the ground. “Hey!” I gasp in indignation.

“Go away,” mumbles the pile of blankets.

I stare at him, frustration burning up in me. “Wow, okay, sorry for caring,” I bite out, my voice dripping with bile as I whirl around and march away. 


[[We barely talk about it for the next few weeks...|Okay]]

links.text: We barely talk about it for the next few weeks...

passages.name: Suggest that Richard's stalking him
passages.text:
Ari gives me a weird look. “What? He’s my boyfriend. That doesn’t even make any sense.” 

[[Sigh|what just happened]]

passages.name: I'm right here for you
passages.text: Relief. “Thanks,” he says. \n\n<<choice "showdown">>

passages.name: Demand he tell me what happened
passages.text:
Nothing,” he spits through clenched teeth, carefully avoiding my stare. “Richard just - his grip was too tight, that’s all.” 

<<choice "Bullshit">>
<<choice "Don't make up excuses for him!">>

passages.name: Intervene: tell him not to yell at my stepbrother
passages.text:
I couldn’t stand the discomfort in my chest anymore. I swiftly stand up, carefully avoiding the chessboard as I hurry into the kitchen. 

“Richard,” I say, almost chastising.

He turns to me with rage-filled eyes, teeth practically grinding. I frown back in disappointment. “What the heck? Don’t yell at my brother like that!”

Richard looks almost taken aback, as if the words had snapped him out of his anger. He stares down at the phone, then back at me in horror, as if I were about to tell him he’s off the team. “Shit, I - I’m so sorry, I,” he stammers, fumbling with the words. 

I raise an eyebrow. “I was just trying to - he was -” Richard struggles to explain himself. “I just snapped, and, yeah, really sorry.”

“You’re still apologizing to //me//?” I say, angling my head towards his phone. He flushes and raise the phone back up to his ear.

“Hey - hey, look, I’m sorry. I shouldn’t have yelled,” he mumbles, clearly humbled. Ari doesn’t seem to appreciate the one-eighty, though, and quickly hangs up. 

It’s quiet in the kitchen. Richard breaks the silence, laughing awkwardly. “Sorry you had to hear that,” he says, clearly mortified.

I frown at him. “It’s - well, do you yell at him like that a lot?”

His eyes widen. “Oh, no no no, trust me, I treat him like an angel, I promise, he just -” he glares at his phone, “he just… tries my patience sometimes.”

“If you say so…”

[[It's a while before ... that. Happens.|what just happened]]

links.text: It's a while before ... that. Happens.

passages.name: Begin
passages.text:
//[[Richard Norbrook]] is now in a relationship with [[Ari Bhardwaj]]//

I frown at my phone, squinting a little to make sure that my brain is processing the names right. //Richard. Ari. Seriously?//

Ari has a Facebook?

Though, while shocking, it wasn’t what stunned me most. 

//Ari// found himself a boyfriend?

I may or may not be jealous, and I could feel my scowl dragging down the corners of my mouth as I tapped his mysterious Facebook page. Seriously, Facebook, for a guy who scorns social interaction itself, let alone social media? 

Well, turns out it was made today. 

Just to broadcast his status to the world. Or for Richard to update his new status officially. Either one seemed plausible. Honestly, those two. 

Wait, no - no! What am I thinking? Richard is too old for Ari - and not just the years thing, but if one also calculated the fact that Ari’s emotional maturity is stuck in the stage of the terrible two’s, Richard is way, way too old. 

I nudge my half-eaten sandwich to the side, focused on my phone. I’ve got to get some more information. Or would that be nosing around in Ari’s business?

At once his scowl pops into my head. //Why don't you just mind your own damn business?// my imagined stepbrother snaps. //Just because your love life is hopeless doesn't mean mine has to be!// Right before slamming a metaphorical door.

Yeah. Not looking forward to that.

Maybe I could ask Richard? Would it be too weird if I asked about my stepbrother? I could just ask as a friend, that wouldn’t be too nosy - right?

His wide smile blooms into being in my mind's mind. //C'mon, Lindy, I'm your best friend, aren't I?// he says, far more pleasantly than Ari ever could, probably with a friendly punch to the shoulder. //Sure, I miiiight drop relationships pretty quick, but you can trust me, right? Right? You can trust your trusty teammate.// Then my imagination says, as if to reply to my question, //It's just a little awkward, y'know. It's really none of your business, is it?//

Honestly, it might just be safest to just to stalk them on Facebook.

<<choice "Text Ari">>
<<choice "Text Richard">>
<<choice "Facebook Stalk">>

passages.name: Okay
passages.text:
"Yo."

I turn my head to see Richard sitting on the curb beside me. "Waiting for the bus, too?" he says.

"Yeah," I sigh. "My car's getting repaired, so."

"Aw, that sucks. What happened? You crash or something?" At the sight of me stiffening he chuckled. "Hey, it's easy to let loose. I can't help but speed over speed bumps. Heh. Speed over speed bumps."

I sputter. "I-I follow the rules of the road to the letter! I would never - and it's very dangerous to do that, speed bumps are there for a //reason// -!"

Richard throws his hands up at the incoming lecture, laughing. "Yeah, yeah, I know, chill, just teasing."

"For your information," I huff, still prickling, "someone crashed into //me//."

"...That sounds like you didn't move out of the way when someone was coming at you."

"I had the right of way," I grumble, crossing my arms. "//They// should've stopped."

"Oh, Lindy," Richard sighs, patting my shoulder. "You poor soul."

"Grr."

A shadow falls over Richard. "Greetings, fellow earthlings," Ari says as he melts to the pavement, wrapping his arms around Richard as he rests his head against Richard's shoulder. "Fellow participants in the pointless race that is life. How are you."

I raise an eyebrow at Ari, who has decided that Richard is now his personal pillow and is now crawling into said pillow's lap. "Er, what exactly were you doing on the bleachers, mister football-hater?"

"Richard wanted me to watch you guys's practice," Ari mumbles into Richard's shirt, now contorted in a position only a being whose bones had been liquified could manage. His eyes slide over to meet mine. "It was boring."

"You didn't even watch," Richard whines. "You were on your phone the whole time."

Ari lifts his chin so that he could somewhat see Richard's face. "The few times I looked up you seemed cool," he says. "Very manly."

As Richard preens, Ari lifts Richard's hand to set it on his head before letting said head fall back onto Richard's shoulder. Richard begins petting Ari's hair in response. 

I consider snapping a photo. If I post it on Facebook or Instagram a bunch of people would leap at the chance to coo at how cute they are. 

And I'll admit. Maybe my initial feelings were a bit off. They seemed to be doing okay. It's almost been a month now - Ari actually gets out of the house for once, if only because Richard begs him to.

"I am now taking your picture. Hold still," I announce, bringing out my phone.

"Noooooooo," Ari says, really dragging out that 'o'.

"You never want to take pictures," Richard says with a pout.

"Pictures are stupid. They live forever," Ari says. "Which sucks for bad pictures."

"What about good ones?" I say, watching as my camera focuses. 

"They deserve to live," Ari says dismissively. "Bad ones should die."

"How do pictures die?" I say, amused.

Richard barks out a laugh. "That's ridiculous, pictures can't die."

"True," I say.

Ari made a grumbling sound. I can only guess that he was irritated that the very serious conversation about dying pictures had been cut off. 

"The bus is coming," Richard says.

"Amazing. Brillaint. Like we couldn't possibly tell," Ari says, voice dripping with ire, and I could feel my muscles tensing at the sound. Great. Ari is in one of his moods again.

"What's got you all grumpy?" Richard says, looking down at Ari.

Ari pulls away and flicks him in the nose. "Figure it out for yourself, dummy." 

"Hey!"

"Don't worry about it," I sigh to Richard as he watches Ari stand and shuffle onto the bus in bewilderment. "He... gets like that sometimes."

"Yeah, no kidding," Richard says. "He was like that the other day. Just like, he suddenly lost interest and didn't want to do //anything//."

"Hey - why did you ask Ari to watch our practice?" I say.

He blinks, probably because the question came out of left field. "Oh, uh," he chuckles, rubbing the back of his neck. "I know he's not that interested in the game or whatever, but... I don't know. I feel weird when he's not there, you know?"

"Uh..."

"I just want to be with him all the time, I guess," Richard says. "You know when you have feelings for someone and you can't think about anything except for them?"

"Uh..."

"Is that weird?"

"...Well. I mean. It hasn't been that long, has it?"

"I don't know. People get together real quick in the movies, don't they? So time shouldn't really matter when it comes to love. Right?"

[[I didn't really think about it for a long time...|Chilling]]

links.text: I didn't really think about it for a long time...

passages.name: Mycle
passages.text:
[img[Mycle's Pic]]

Age: 15 (Sophmore)
Gender: Male
Has cerebral palsy and a suspicious Internet history (a writer's gotta do their research)
Values: love, peace, and a good book
Here to help

[[Go Back|what just happened]]

passages.name: ari are you okay
passages.text:
Ari is acting even more irritated and miserable than usual at dinner, barely eating. 

It gets so bad that his mom finally snaps, sending him to wash the dishes afterwards - though, naturally, Ari isn’t going to do that without showing his great distaste for the show as passive-aggressively as possible.

I’m curled up on the futon with a book, cringing as there comes another loud clang from the kitchen. I look up, having the perfect view of Ari washing the dishes from my seat, and grind my teeth as Ari heaves another soapy plate from the sink and dumps it carelessly into the dish dryer. 

There comes the horrible sound of plates scraping together, of cups clinking way too loudly against each other, the splashes and thunks that had me on the edge of my seat just waiting for the cracking sound of something breaking. 

I groan and thump my book against my head. Usually Rajni would be there to force her son to do things her way - usually prompting Ari to do the complete opposite - but tonight she’s clearly had enough and has locked herself in her and Dad’s bedroom.

Suddenly there’s an ugh from the kitchen.

“My sleeve’s getting weeeeet,” Ari whines.

That’s it.

I spring from the futon and march into the kitchen. I could only glare at Ari for a few moments before gritting out, “What the heck.”

“My sleeve’s getting wet,” Ari says.

One of his sleeves is already rolled up. The other is left down, water creeping up the fabric.

I inhale deeply. “Then,” I say, keeping a careful hold on my patience, “Why don’t you roll it up?”

His mouth turns into a thin, tense line. “Don’t want to.”

Oh. 

My. 

God.

<<choice "Tell him to roll up his sleeves and do it right">>
<<choice "Roll up sleeve for him">>
<<choice "Take over washing the dishes">>

passages.name: The broken robot
passages.text: “Whatever,” Ari mumbles. “It was a piece of junk anyway. Everything I make is shit.” His eyes are sad. I can’t remember the last time I saw him tinkering away, lost in his passionate work.\n\n[[He used to love it|Talk about something else]]

passages.name: Drag him out of bed
passages.text:
“That’s it,” I say with a finality in my voice, grabbing a handful of blanket and dragging them off the bed. Ari let out a squawk of indignation, curling in on himself and throwing the pillow over his head to block out the sun. 
“Oh, no, you don’t -” I grab hold of his ankles and pull. Like expected, Ari began yowling and clinging to the bedsheets, but they betrayed him as they followed him off the bed in a miserable heap. “Come on, get up and get some food in you, this is ridiculous,” I snap at the groaning pile at my feet. 

When Ari refuses to stir, I roll my eyes and bend down to tuck my arms under his and haul him up. “God you stink, go take a shower!” Ari responds by going limp. I stare down at him, unimpressed, as I had already braced myself for such a tactic. I made sure to growl in irritation as I drag him to the bathroom and all but throw him in. 

“I’m going to go make you some breakfast,” I say, frowning at him as he reluctantly draws himself up into a sitting position. “Or, lunch, I guess. No, sorry, it’s way too late for that, isn’t it? Ugh, either way, you better have taken care of yourself, got it?”

He sticks out his tongue and slams the door. I scoff - how childish!

Fifteen minutes later, Ari’s sitting at the table, clothes changed, hair brushed, and face looking like he’d rather be in bed as he stares at the waffles I had thrown together. “I’m not hungry,” he says, pushing the plate away.

I, snacking on cashews, push the plate back at him. “You haven’t eaten all day.”

“‘Cause I’m not hungry.” His stomach growls in disagreement.

“You gotta be kidding me. Just take a bite, trust me, you’ll be reminded of just how hungry you are.”

“No.” He takes a bite anyway, leaning his chin on his palm as he douses his waffles in maple syrup. Dork.

The sunlight peeks in through the half-opened blinds, spilling golden onto the table as we eat in the quiet of the afternoon. 

“Feeling better?”
“... yeah.”

[[A few weeks pass. We barely talk about Richard.|Okay]]

links.text: A few weeks pass. We barely talk about Richard.

passages.name: Intervene: tell him not to yell at his boyfriend
passages.text:
I couldn’t stand the uncomfortable atmosphere any longer and stand up in a hurry, knocking over the chessboard in the process. Pieces go flying as I walk into the kitchen. 

“Richard,” I say, “what the heck?”

He turns his glare on me. My muscles twitch, wanting to take a step back, but I resist the urge. Richard visibly makes the effort to soften his face and places a hand over the receiver. “What?”

“Don’t yell at your boyfriend like that!” I say, unable to keep the appalled note from my voice.

His face crinkles back into indignant fury. “It’s none of your business,” he snaps at me. “He’s //my// boyfriend.”

The possessive bite in his voice is what makes me step back, embarrassment rushing through me. “Sorry,” I mumble.

I shuffle back to the chess board, Richard returning to the fight over the phone at full volume. Pretty soon, it ends with Richard storming out of the kitchen, face red and teeth clenched. 

“Gotta go,” was his curt farewell as he flies out the door. 

[[Later that day]]

passages.name: go to the group meeting
passages.text:
Mycle
//hi Lindy, hope i’m not bothering you, but i was wondering if you know where Ari is? we were supposed to meet for our group project - but he isn’t answering his phone.//

I frown at my phone, then hit speed dial. I breathe in relief when I hear Ari’s voice on the other side. 

“Hey Ari, where are you? Your group’s waiting for you,” I say.

“I can’t make it.”

“What?”

“I can’t go to the group meeting.” 

His voice sounds resignated.

I listen closely. I hear cars. People bustling about. “Where are you?”

Richard’s voice. “C’mon, wrap it up.”

“Tell Mycle sorry,” Ari says, sounding seconds from hanging up. 

<<choice "Tell Ari to go to the meeting, NOW">>
<<choice "Call Mycle and tell him to call Ari and get him to go to the meeting">>
<<choice "Call Mycle and tell him Ari's not coming">>

passages.name: Just listen
passages.text:
“These thoughts keep coming, going round and round and round like a fucking merry-go-round, and sometimes I just want to stop thinking… I just want it all to stop…”

I let Ari talk until his head is limp against my shoulder and his voice sounds like wheels running over gravel. 

He falls silent. 

The room is quiet, swollen with amber light. It’s dark outside.

[[We stay there for a while.|go to the group meeting]]

links.text: We stay there for a while.

passages.name: Stop Him
passages.text:
I jump out of my seat. “Richard! Cut it out!” I snap, striding swiftly to cut Richard off. Richard stops short, glaring down at me. 

“Get out of my way,” he growls, Ari still trying to rip his arm away. 

“They weren’t doing anything!”

“Please! You think I wouldn’t notice some other guy having eyes for someone who’s //mine//?” 

“I’m not your fucking //dog//!” Ari snarls, wrenching his arm away. The two of them glower fiercely at each other.

I couldn’t help but grow hyper aware of the fact that there were eyes on all of us. Just the thought made me want to slink back to the table with Mycle. My fingernails bit into my sweaty palms. 

“Guys, please,” I plead, desperate to grab control of the situation and get those eyes off us. 

But any hope for control, if there had been any, quickly slipped from my fingers as Ari and Richard completely ignore me and begin yelling at each other, an explosive fight that I almost feared if I stepped too close, I would get sucked in.

Ari is the one to cut off the fight, marching past Richard and flying out of the cafeteria.

[[ari are you okay]]

passages.name: the break up
passages.text:
Ari is depressed.

Not like sad, or like moping. 

Like he is diagnosed with depression.

It started with Mycle, who was kinder than me, cleverer than me, who let Ari feel more comfortable talking about the hopelessness and despair that threatened to eat him from the inside out, who guided Ari to the school counselor that Mycle himself sees frequently. 

I don’t really know much, only told, that after a long process of testing at the doctor’s, Ari came away with a plan of antidepressants and therapy. As grumpy as he still was, the cloud of irritability that seemed to follow him around seemed to ease, and he stopped sleeping so much. 

But other than that, I couldn’t see much of a difference.

It scared me.

How easily it slipped by under my nose. How invisible it was. How hidden it lay tucked within the confines of Ari’s mind, safely stowed away from anyone’s sight, only brought to the light by Ari’s own words. The aching feeling of hopelessness. The weight of the anchor of self-loathing and the hollow feeling of worthlessness. The running cycle of thoughts of death.

And what about Richard?

Ari still clung to the relationship. I don’t understand it. Ari says I can’t understand it, because I’ve never been in a relationship. Harsh. 

But I think he knew that it was eating away at him. It was eating away at both of them. Because he came up to me today and said, “I need your help.”

“I need your help,” he says. “I need to break up with Richard.”

<<choice "What do you need me for?">>
<<choice "Finally">>
<<choice "I'm right here for you">>

passages.name: Nothing
passages.text:
Ari curls up in bed. I turn out the lights.

[[He sleeps|go to the group meeting]]

passages.name: StoryTitle
passages.text: To Be There

passages.name: Richard's Pic
passages.text: data:image/jpeg;base64,

passages.name: Go to him after he has time to cool down
passages.text:
After settling on my decision, I could only cringe when I hear screaming and a crash coming from Ari’s room. After a good hour or so, I hesitantly knock on the door. 

There’s a moment of silence, and Ari opens the door. 

His eyes are red. 

He lets me in. 

There’s a pile of broken mechanical parts swept up in the corner. The little thing he made for that robotics competition was nowhere to be found.

[[Talk about the bruise]]
[[Talk about something else]]

passages.name: Bullshit
passages.text:
I never swear - I give Ari flak for his language - so Ari’s eyes widen almost comedically at the rare curse. But the tension hovering around him snapped at the accusation. “What do you know? You don’t know anything!” he yelled before chucking his sponge into the sink and marching into our room.
 
[[our room]]

passages.name: You should do this yourself
passages.text:
It’s too awkward, I said. It’s a private thing, I argued.

Who was I trying to convince?


<<choice "aftermath">>

passages.name: what just happened
passages.text:
[[Mycle]] has a thoughtful look on his face as he chews his sushi. “That… does not sound particularly healthy,” he admits.

I groan and rest my head on my forearms. “I know, but what can I do? What if I’m overreacting? Ari won’t listen to me either way, and I don’t really feel comfortable telling Richard what to do - I mean, I’d be technically interfering with his love life.”

Mycle looks concerned. “You wouldn’t want it to go too far before intervening either, though.”

“I know, I know!” I say grumpily, causing Mycle to shrink back.

“S-sorry, I didn’t mean -”

“It’s fine,” I say, waving a hand. “It’s just - man, it’s tricky.”

“It’s a fine balance,” Mycle agrees. “Just… keep an eye on him? Gah, I feel awkward saying so -”

“Lindy,” comes a voice, and I look over my shoulder to see Ari scowling at me. I hear an unidentifiable squeak coming from Mycle. “Did you see Richard?” 

“No,” I say, bemused.

“Good,” he says, proceeding to drop to the floor and crawl under the cafeteria table. 

I squawk in alarm, lifting my feet as Ari bumps into them. “What the heck!”

“I’ll explain later. Don’t tell anybody I’m here,” comes Ari’s voice. 

I look over the table to exchange an exasperated look with Mycle, but my gaze only met a very blushy friend. I raise an eyebrow. He pulls up his turtleneck to hide his face. 

“So, Mycle,” I say casually. “Have you met Ari?”

“Yeah, we’re in Biotech together.” Ari’s voice is somehow loud enough to be heard from under the table in a loud cafeteria. “We’ve just started working on a group project. Mycle’s really good at drawing, by the way.”

Mycle sinks deeper into his sweater.

“You know, we could have this conversation with you not under the table,” I tell Ari dryly.

“Nah, not until I know Richard’s not gonna find me in here,” he says. 

My eyebrows knit together. “Why don’t you want Richard to find you?”

“I may or may not have ignited his rage.”

I groan into my palm. “Ari, what did you do?”

Ari mutters something I couldn’t possibly hear. Probably on purpose. 

So, I lean over the table to talk quietly to Mycle. “Sooo,” I say, drawing out the syllable. Mycle sinks lower in his seat. 

“... he’s really sweet,” I think I hear. 

I’m staring at him in disbelief when I catch sight of Richard, looking around the cafeteria almost desperately before leaving. I poke Ari with my foot. “Hey, you can come out now.”

Ari crawls out and clambers into the seat next to Mycle, who looks ready to keel over from too much blood in the face. “Phew,” he says. “Hey, sushi. Can I have one?” 

Mycle musters a shy nod, a tiny smile starting to grow on his face. “Sweet,” Ari says, grabbing one and popping it in his mouth.

“Dude!” I say, aghast.

“What?”

“You just touched the ground with those fingers!”

“So? It’s not your stomach,” Ari says.

Mycle’s trying and failing to stifle his snickers. I give him a glare. 

“Fine, then. Let’s talk about you avoiding Richard,” I say.

Ari’s face drops into a scowl. “No.”

“Come on, is there something wrong?”

“No, it’s just -” Ari huffs out an irritated sigh. “He thought I was looking at some other guy and started yelling at me for it. He was just being a jerk, that’s all. Can we talk about something else, now?”

“Like the yellow glass beaker?” Mycle pipes up innocently. Their eyes meet, and the two of them just burst into uncontrollable laughter. I stare at them. They’re just helplessly giggling like it’s the funniest thing in the world.

“What. What’s happening,” I say flatly.

“S-sorry,” Mycle stammers, successfully overcoming his laughter. Ari’s still dying next to him. “Inside joke.”

I stare some more, then I throw a hand over my heart. “Ari! Have you stolen my best friend?”

“Pff,” leaves Ari’s mouth. “~I stole your best friend~” he sing-songs, throwing his arms around Mycle. “Mwahahaha.” 

I roll my eyes at Ari’s antics and the fact that Mycle has a partially panicked, partially overjoyed look on his face. Ari remains draped over him, clearly enjoying his new personal pillow. 

“Wow,” I say, my hand still over my heart. “Amazing. Such betrayed.”

“S-stop, it’s not like that,” Mycle protests, his face still red. I hope he’s letting himself breathe. 

“I’m just teasing you,” I reassure him with a grin.

Then things go downhill.

Richard’s voice came out of nowhere. Ari freezes, eyes wide as if he were caught in a search beam, before quickly releasing Mycle. I spin around in my seat to see Richard storming in, eyes locked on Ari, who was standing up. 

“Look, it wasn’t -” 

“As if,” Richard snarls, throwing Mycle a Look of Death, causing him to shrink low in his seat in terror. “You’re coming with me,” he says, grabbing hold of Ari’s arm and dragging him off. 

Ari yelps and kicks at Richard’s shin. “Fuck you, let go! That hurts!”

<<choice "Stop Him">>
<<choice "Go After Them">>
<<choice "Stay Back">>

passages.name: showdown
passages.text:
Ari meets up with Richard. “We need to talk,” he says.

And Richard laughs at first.

Then his laughter fades and turns into disbelief.

His disbelief quickly morphs into anger.

And oh, how fierce and angry are the words they exchange. Pain. Rage. Hurt. Somehow, I think, they both desperately wanted to both hurt the other and keep the other from hurt. But they are both clumsy with their words, imprecise, and it hurts even more.

Richard is so close to snapping, but his eyes keep darting to me, restless, as if my presence is the only thing keeping him from lunging. I think he knew if he tried, he would get a very, very painful greeting to the groin.

It ends messily.

Ari looks both relieved and heartbroken.

Mycle meets us at our apartment. We eat ice cream and cry at Pixar movies, and everything’s okay and not okay. 

But time marches on. Ari forgets to take his medicine sometimes and I remind him. Mycle reaches out to greet Ari with a hug every time he sees him. Richard sometimes tries to win Ari back. When I look over Ari’s shoulder I see him looking up stuff about testosterone and binders. Mycle comes over more often. Ari hesitantly begins to make more friends. Time is moving forward, and we’re not being left behind.

[[We pick up the pieces, and we carry them to wherever our paths take us.]]

links.text: We pick up the pieces, and we carry them to wherever our paths take us.

destination.name: We pick up the pieces, and we carry them to wherever our paths take us.

passages.name: You should face him on your own
passages.text:
It’s too awkward. It’s a private thing. 

Who was I trying to convince?

<<choice "aftermath">>

passages.name: Roll up sleeve for him
passages.text:
Impatient and frustrated at his childishness, I rolled his sleeve up for him like I used to do when we were kids and he wouldn’t do it himself because he didn’t want to get his sleeves wet. 

What I didn’t expect was a nasty bruise, right about where Richard grabbed him earlier. Before I could finish gawking Ari ripped his arm away, eyes blazing. “What the f*ck!” he shrieked, shoving his sleeve back down. Words of apology rose to my lips before frustration took over. There’s a screaming fest and Ari marches off to his room. 

<<choice "our room">>

passages.name: Anything
passages.text:
Anything. I talk about the weather, how annoying teachers can be, how hard math is, why being team captain is both awesome and terrible, all the silly little small talk Ari hates. 

[[He listens, as if clinging to it.|Talk about something else]]

links.text: He listens, as if clinging to it.

passages.name: Take over washing the dishes
passages.text:
“Oh my god, let me,” I snapped, my heart aching at the sight of poorly washed dishes. But Ari, ever stubborn and petty, had the audacity to sneer. 

“Is this bothering you?” he says, more angry than teasing. We then began wrestling for the dishes, yelling and splashing soapy water everywhere and making Ari’s mom yell at us and my dad to inquire curiously about the commotion in the kitchen. 

We were both put on dish-washing duty. 

Neither of us are happy. 

“Why do you have to drag me into your messes?” I grumble as I dry a cup and hand it to Ari to put it away.

“You get yourself dragged into my messes,” Ari says, opening the cupboard. 

I turn around to glare at him. “How so?” I demand.

He rolls his eyes as he reaches up to slip the cup into its rightful place. “You’re always butting into my business,” he says. “Maybe if you kept your nose out of -”

But his words are lost on me, for my eye has caught sight of the ugly bruise that has formed on his forearm, revealed as his sleeve falls from reaching upwards. 

“Ari, what is that?” I demand, instinctively reaching for his arm. “Isn’t that where Richard grabbed you?”

Alarm darts over his face as he hurriedly pushes his sleeve down. “It’s,” he starts, but doesn’t seem to find the words. His eyes are lost, almost ashamed. “It’s none of your business,” he tosses into my face, trying to inject anger in there as he darts out of the kitchen, the door to our room slamming shut.

[[our room]]

passages.name: Text Richard
passages.text:
//Lindy
Hey Richard, I might have noticed your new status and might have gotten a little curious. What's up with you and Ari?//

Totally not weird. I cringe as I reread my text and sigh. Why hasn’t technology granted us a way to delete send texts yet?

As I prod the soggy bread of my sandwich sorrowfully, the text alert sprang from my phone. I blink down at it in surprise. “That was fast," I inform my phone as I pick it up.

<<choice "Warn Richard">> 
<<choice "Wish Richard Good Luck">>

passages.name: Mycle's Pic
passages.text: data:image/jpeg;base64,

passages.name: Go After Them
passages.text:
I quickly stand and begin following them, weaving between the tables as my eye carefully tracks their backs. We finally emerge out into the open, with only a few students walking past us, fewer still giving us odd looks. 

Ari has been screaming expletives at Richard, who finally throws him off hard enough to send Ari stumbling towards the ground. 

“Richard! Richard! Stop it!” I yell, rushing up to them. 

Richard’s eyes are hard when they meet mine. 

“What do you think you’re doing!” My voice has risen to a shriek, but I barely notice, for Richard’s face is morphing. He staggers back from me, hands up. 

“Sorry, sorry, I’m sorry -”

“Fuck you!” Ari spits as he drags himself up and off the ground. 

“Ari -”

“Stay the fuck away from me,” Ari says bitterly, turning to rush off. 

We stare after him. The wind is cold. 

[[ari are you okay]]

passages.name: Stay Back
passages.text:
I stare helplessly after them.

“Sh-shouldn’t we go after them?” Mycle squeaks. 

I cringe at the thought of tiny Mycle facing the hulking, angry figure of Richard. “No, no, don’t worry about it, Richard wouldn’t hurt him,” I say. At Mycle’s worried look, I am quick to reassure him. “Really, I know him. Richard might have a temper, but he’s really a good person.”

Mycle doesn’t look convinced, but as he looks back over where Richard and Ari disappeared, he wears a resignated face. 

“Don’t worry about Ari,” I say again, wondering who I’m trying to convince. “He’ll be okay.”

[[ari’s not okay]]

passages.name: Pretend I didn't see anything
passages.text:
My eyes quickly roll off his forearm, and the tension in his shoulders seem to ease up.

[[The way he continued washing the dishes seems melancholy.|go to the group meeting]]

links.text: The way he continued washing the dishes seems melancholy.

passages.name: Later that day
passages.text:
Ari crashes through the door, his face lit with rage.

I look over at the clock from where I’m sitting at the kitchen table. “It’s late,” I observe.

“Wow. Amazing. Stunning. I couldn’t possibly figure that out by myself,” Ari snips at me as he chucks his backpack at the futon. 

I stare at him as he furiously rips out his notebook. “Are you okay?”

Ari throws his hands in the air, notebook sent flying. “No! I am not okay!” he yells. “Richard’s so -” he struggles for a moment. “Clingy!” he says finally, his voice full of exasperation.

“Because he was angry at you for not texting him back?”

“No, not just that!” Ari snaps, flapping his hands as he paces rapidly as if his frustration was too much to hold. “He like, seems to need to be around me all the time. It’s so annoying - he like, shows up at the end of my fourth period so we can have lunch together right away, even though I never told him my schedule, and he just. Doesn’t. Leave. Me. Alone.”

He spreads his arms, a bewildered look on his face. “It’s like, I’m fine with hanging out with him and all, but sometimes I don’t feel like doing anything, alright? I just don’t have the energy for it! And he! Doesn’t! Get it! Ugh!”

He jumps onto the futon and spins around. “And just now he went all the way to the library just to scream at me for not texting him! Not texting him! Like, oh my gosh, can you get more petty?”

<<choice "Suggest that Ari's complaining is too much">>
<<choice "Suggest that Richard simply cares about him a lot">>
<<choice "Suggest that Richard's stalking him">>

passages.name: Try to give him advice
passages.text:
At another time I might’ve been insulted. “What about me? Or Rajni?”

Ari barks out a laugh. “You’re family. You’re obligated.” 

I think of Mycle. “There are still people who care about you, Ari.”

“Psh.”

“Really.”

“They’re pretending.”

“Ari -”

“They wouldn’t be affected if I were gone,” he says, his voice pained. He presses his face against my shoulder. “It’d be better if I’m gone.” His voice is but a muffled whisper.

I clutch him. “That’s not true.”

He’s quiet, but shaking his head.

What do I do?

What can I do?

[[I don't know. I don't know.|go to the group meeting]]

links.text: I don't know. I don't know.

passages.name: Lecture him
passages.text:
“You can’t just sleep the day away!” I exclaim in exasperation. “You’ll miss school, then you’ll mess up your sleep schedule, and -” 

A pillow cuts me off mid-sentence. I step back and sputter in indignation, glaring at the mound of blankets before me. “Fine!” I snap, stomping out of the room. Clearly he wasn’t going to listen to me. Why even bring up Richard?

[[We barely talk about it for the next few weeks...|Okay]]

links.text: We barely talk about it for the next few weeks...

passages.name: ari’s not okay
passages.text:
When Ari comes home that day, he goes straight for the room, walking swiftly. 

<<choice "I need to help him">>
<<choice "He'll just yell at me">>

passages.name: Call Mycle and tell him to call Ari and get him to go to the meeting

links.text: How can you know for sure?

passages.name: Tell him to roll up his sleeves and do it right
passages.text:
“If you roll up your sleeve,” I say, quickly losing my grip on my patience, “it won’t get wet.”

A pause.

“I don’t want to roll up my sleeve, though.”

“Just roll it up.”

“No.”

“Do. It.”

“No.”

“Please, I can’t take any more of this complaining.”

“... No.”

I crack.

“Why not!” I burst out. “What are you hiding!” 

There’s a tense moment of silence. My breath stops in my throat.

“Ari…?”

<<choice "Freak out">>
<<choice "Demand he tell me what happened">>
<<choice "Pretend I didn't see anything">>

passages.name: Chilling
passages.text:
Richard pulls out his phone for the second hundredth time and frowns. 

“Dude,” I say. 

“Sorry, sorry,” he says, tucking his phone into his pocket and leaning back over the chessboard. “...is it my turn?” 

“No, it’s still mine,” I sigh as I poke my rook into the space next to it. “Is something up?”

“Ari hasn’t texted me back,” Richard said, his mouth a tight line. 

I rub the space between my eyes. “Richard. Ari isn’t going to reply immediately every time you send him a text. I mean, he’s probably the laziest person in the world.” 

“But it’s been //hours//,” he gripes, pulling out his phone and punching in another text instead of taking his turn.

“It’s been twenty minutes.”

“What else could he be doing?” Richard mutters, glaring at the screen of his phone.

I chuckle. “Believe it or not, he does have a life outside of his phone.”

“What life? I’m not there,” Richard grumbles.

My eyebrows climb upwards. “Ouch.”

He groans and facepalms. “I did not. Mean for that to come out the way it did.”

My thumb taps against my thigh awkwardly as Richard turns his attention back to the board. “Uh, let’s go this way,” he mutters to his knight, leaping out of the way of my rook. 

I slide my waiting bishop into place. “Checkmate.”

His jaw drops and his eyes widen. Ah, my favorite part of the game.

“How - but - when -?”

I fold my arms neatly across the table, grinning. “I’m a team captain, I have to be good at strategy and reading my opponent,” I say teasingly, knocking the pieces off the board to start again.

“Ohhhh,” he says, nodding as if I said something wise.

“Psh, nah, not really, I just used to play chess all the time with Ari when we were younger. I know all the tricks now,” I say.

Richard grins. “Was he good?”

I groan. “He would //crush// me, it was annoying.”

“Like him not texting me back,” Richard grumbles, pulling out his phone //again//.

I shift uncomfortably. “You know, Richard -”

“I’m gonna call him,” Richard says.

“Wha -”

“Just - just to make sure he’s alright,” he says, standing and going into the other room. 

I stare at the chess pieces lying on their sides as Richard’s voice floats back into the room. 

“Hey babe, did you get my texts?” it says. There’s a strained tone. “Well, why didn’t you text me back?” 

I tuck the pieces into their proper places, trying not to eavesdrop. 

“No - no, don’t be silly,” light, or at least trying to be, “that’s stupid, why would you even think that?” curt, sharp, “what the fuck, am I not allowed to want to spend time with you? God! Blah blah blah - you always say you’re busy but then I find out you’re just lying around at home doing //nothing//! Yeah I asked Lindy, what of it? Well - yeah, I went to your place to see if - well what was I supposed to do? Don’t give me that bullshit, you’re always talking to me like I’m some -! There! There you go again! Being all bitchy, that’s what! Wha -”
Richard’s voice abruptly cuts off, then rose in volume as he swore so viciously I subconsciously hunch in on myself, grimacing. 

My phone alerts me to a text, and when I pull it out I see Ari’s text. //Is he there rn?//

I peek into the kitchen, seeing Richard scream “PICK UP!” at his phone. //Yeah.//

//fuck. why.//

//He came over looking for you, so when I told him you weren’t here he decided to wait here?

what the fuuuuuck who does that 

We’re playing chess to pass the time

course u are

He’s yelling in the kitchen. I think he wants you to pick up.

ugh. //

A moment later Richard’s yelling again. “What the //heck//? You don’t just //ignore// your boyfriend, you bitch! Your //boyfriend//!”

My fingers twitch, causing a queen to tumble off the board. I've seen Richard blow his top numerous times on the field when things didn't go his way - he never means any harm, and always apologizes afterwards. But still, my skin squirms to hear him lay his frustrations on Ari. Should I really get involved?

<<choice "It’s his boyfriend, let him talk to him the way he wants">>
<<choice "Intervene: tell him not to yell at his boyfriend">>
<<choice "Intervene: tell him not to yell at my stepbrother">>

passages.name: something is wrong
passages.text:
Ari doesn’t come home.

Instead, Richard sends Rajni a text, saying that Ari’s staying over at his place.

I don’t feel good about it. At all. But Rajni and Dad shrug and say that Richard’s a nice boy.

I don’t know how to tell them. About the yelling, about the bruise.

I don’t know if my mind will allow me to tell myself. I thought I knew Richard. I do know Richard. I don’t want to hurt him either.

Ari comes back the next morning.

[[He looks tired.|the break up]]

passages.name: Of course
passages.text:
Relief. “Thanks,” he says. 

<<choice "showdown">>

passages.name: Rush after him
passages.text:
I push the door open, seeing Ari perched on his bed. He looks up, face drawn. “What are you doing in here?” he demands, anger flooding his face. 
“It’s my room, too!”

“No no no, get out! You’re just going to ask me stupid questions!” Ari snarls, jumping off the bed to push me out the door.

“I’m trying to help you!” I say desperately, standing my ground pretty well. Even though Ari is way taller than me, he’s still a scrawny kid shoving at a seasoned athlete.

Something about that made him stop in his tracks, staring at my shoulder. It takes me a moment to realize his eyes are filling with tears. 

“Fuck,” he mutters, sinking to the floor. I sink with him. 

He falls forward, leaning against my side as he wraps his arms around himself. I hug him close. “It’s… it’s not the only one,” he admits in a small voice. 

It’s quiet. 

“I - I never know what to think. Sometimes he’s great, you know?” His voice is tight. “Most of the time he’s… the best. He’s smart and clever and takes me to interesting places. But we just - get into these huge fights, you know.” 

He sniffs. “He loses his temper a lot. Like me, I guess. But he… really loses it.” 

I rub his arm. I hope it’s soothing. 

“Then the next day he’ll come to my doorstep with flowers and apologies and I just - I don’t know. I keep thinking it would be the last time, or that if I left him I’d never - nobody else would - I’d have nobody else, everybody else hates me.” 

<<choice "Try to give him advice">>
<<choice "Just listen">>

passages.name: Warn Ari
passages.text:
//Lindy
It’s still a bad idea. You’re so much younger.

Ari

Lindy

Ari.
hm. dont care

ARI

Lindy
What would people think?! What would your mom think???

Ari
would probably hate it

Ari
which means it’d be hilarious to do anyway lol

Lindy

Lindy
ARI//

Ari sent a picture of him flipping the bird. I could only stare at it in astonishment. Is he still in bed?!

The bell rang; lunch’s over. I huffed and stuck the phone in my pocket. 

[[Looks like I’ll have to wait to yell at him.|At Home]]

links.text: Looks like I’ll have to wait to yell at him.

passages.name: Don't make up excuses for him!
passages.text:
This seems to snap something in Ari. He could only shriek “Shut up!” at me before shoving past me and storming into his room. 

<<choice "our room">>

passages.name: Freak out
passages.text:
Ari throws down the sponge, clearly intending for it to splash but it only flopped miserably into the water-filled sink. “Maybe that’s f*cking why I didn’t want to f*cking show you,” he snarls before marching off to his room. 

<<choice "our room">>

passages.name: Suggest that Ari's complaining is too much
passages.text:
Ari gapes at me before scowling and jumping off the futon, stomping away as he mutters under his breath that I never take him seriously.

“Remind me never to talk to you about this stuff again,” he grumbles as he passes.

[[Oh dear|what just happened]]

passages.name: At Home
passages.text:
I unlock the door to my apartment, shoving the door open as I stuffed my keychain back into the front pocket of my backpack. “I’m home!” I call, kicking my shoes off. No response.

I swung my backpack over to land onto the futon and sigh heavily, letting my shoulders slump forward as I dragged myself into the room I share with Ari.

As I push the door open and meander over to my desk, the covers on Ari’s bed shifted abruptly. I shriek and jump in surprise. 

“ARI!” I yell, my voice louder than I intended.

Ari groans audibly and his head pokes out from under his blankets. He glares blearily at me. “What the fuck, Lindy,” he says, voice groggy. 

I blink, then scowl viciously. “What the heck are you doing still in bed?” I demand, placing a hand on my hip. “It’s four in the afternoon!” 

“Oh no, the horror,” he grumbles as he throws the blankets back over his head.

“Have you been sleeping all day?” I say incredulously. My mind scampers to find other reasons. “Unless - are you on your period?” I say, a bit more sympathetic. 

“No,” he says, erasing my sympathy immediately. “I just wanted to test out how long I can stay in bed without needing to get up to eat or take a piss. Sleep’s nice when the sun’s not shining in your face.”

“There’s a reason we don’t sleep when the sun’s up,” I say dryly. “Instead, we do things like go to school. Which, by the way, you clearly missed!”

“Ughhh.”

“What’s with you? You’ve been sleeping way more lately.”

“When you’re constantly questioning the fragile fabric of your existence, sleep’s by far a much better option,” Ari drawls, dramatically flopping over to his other side. “Good night.”

[[Lecture him]]
[[Drag him out of bed]]
[[Ask him if he's okay]]

passages.name: Ari's Pic
passages.text: data:image/jpeg;base64,

passages.name: Facebook Stalk
passages.text:
Already people are commenting on Richard’s new status, congratulating him. 

Richard always did have a lot of friends.

Not many of his friends would know Ari, I’d bet. He’s not exactly popular amongst people of his own age group. 

I scrolled through Richard’s timeline - one post caught my attention: //met someone at the game last night. taking him to the science museum tmw!//

I blink at the picture - when I first scrolled past it I barely registered the figure in dark lighting, but now that I stare at it I see Ari’s curly hair, his familiar profile. 

I lean back, bewildered. 

[[I'll talk to Ari at home|At Home]]

links.text: I'll talk to Ari at home

passages.name: Wish Richard Good Luck
passages.text:
//Lindy
I can only say, good luck.

Richard
heh, i cant tell if that’s your blessing or sarcasm

Richard
thanks, tho

Lindy
Sure.//

I drop the phone and tilt my head back with a sigh as the bell rings. What did I just do?


[[Can’t wait to get home|At Home]]

passages.name: I'm going to get you, where are you?
passages.text:
“Where…?” I can hear the surprise in his voice. “At - at the movie theater.”

“I’m coming, okay? Hang in here.”

“O-okay.” An even quieter “thanks” before he hangs up. 

[[I’ve never been happier I’ve got my driver’s license.|the place]]

links.text: I’ve never been happier I’ve got my driver’s license.

passages.name: Call Mycle and tell him Ari's not coming
passages.text:
“Oh. Okay.” Mycle’s voice is quiet.

My stomach twists in uncertainty.

I wonder if Mycle would’ve gotten through to Ari. 

[[something is wrong]]

passages.name: Wish Ari Good Luck
passages.text:
I swallow, pressing a finger against my mouth in thought. Ari seems to actually like Richard. Which would be saying a lot for anybody. And it’s not like I don’t trust my friend and team mate - I knew him well, always working hard with a grin, even if he was a bit hot-headed at times. 

Though I couldn’t understand why he would want to ask Ari out. Ari. The kid drenched in black slouching around the place with a scowl on his face. Who would jump and hiss if you so much bumped into him. Would never pick up his stuff, stays up ridiculously late, and screeches like a banshee if you irritated him just the slightest bit.

Maybe I was little biased.

//At least it’s Richard//, the little voice in my head whispered. Someone I know I can trust.

//Lindy
I’m still not convinced it’ll work out

Lindy
But good luck, I guess.

Ari
so glad to have ur undying support//

I rolled my eyes at the sarcasm and, at the sound of the bell, pocketed my phone.

[[I'll see him at home|At Home]]

passages.name: Suggest that Richard simply cares about him a lot
passages.text:
Ari pauses, looking like he’s contemplating my words. “Makes sense, I guess,” he says.

[[Definitely|what just happened]]

passages.name: StoryAuthor
passages.text: Serene Sherman & Emil Ingemansson

passages.name: Tell Ari to go to the meeting, NOW
passages.text:
“I don’t think Richard would let me,” Ari says. He sounds resigned.

<<choice "I'm going to get you, where are you?">>
<<choice "He's not the boss of you.">>

passages.name: It’s his boyfriend, let him talk to him the way he wants
passages.text:
I awkwardly wait for the escalating fight to end. Richard’s yelling so loudly I can’t help but feel relieved that nobody else is home yet. 

Finally Richard barks out his last word, and the sudden silence that befell the apartment felt cold. Richard storms out of the kitchen, his face completely red. “I’ve got to go, bye Lindy, see you tomorrow,” fell out of his mouth in a rush, as if to make sure the pleasantries were still there before he swept out of the house.

I sit there with a chessboard ready to play, stunned. 

[[Later that day]]

passages.name: Talk About Mycle
passages.text:
For the first time in what feels like a long time, Ari’s eyes light up. “That guy’s like a fucking Disney princess, I swear,” he says. “I wouldn’t be surprised if birds and deer just walk up to him in the middle of the forest. I have to be careful Richard doesn’t see me talking to him, though - he gets super jealous for some reason.” 

[[I wonder why|Talk about something else]]

passages.name: Lindy's Pic
passages.text: data:image/jpeg;base64,
